author: By Carlotta Gall
title: An Exhibit Meant to Showcase Kurdish Suffering Provoked a Furor Instead
description: A recent art show in a major Kurdish city in Turkey aimed to uplift a region crushed by years of conflict. It ended up serving as a reminder of how toxic the subject of Kurds remains in Turkey.
content: DIYARBAKIR, Turkey — Dozens of brightly painted coffins marked with the initials of dead Kurdish civilians were laid out on the upper battlements of an ancient fortress. A wall of street signs bearing the names of other victims and a towering pile of rubber shoes recalled the thousands killed or imprisoned during decades of conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: The Work in My Building Is Endless and Invasive. Can I Withhold Rent?
description: A landlord is entitled to reasonable access to a tenant’s apartment. But there are limits, and now is not a good time to be fighting with renters.
content: Q: We live in a penthouse apartment with a wraparound roof terrace in a large high-rise in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. Two weeks ago, a maintenance crew arrived unannounced to erect an enormous gantry on the terrace in order to access windows  below that need repairs. We were told the work would take a few days, but they’re nowhere near finished. Since the crews require access to our apartment to reach the terrace, they come and go at all hours, sometimes arriving before we are out of bed, and traipse through all day. While they work, we have no privacy unless we lower all the blinds and sit in the dark. The workers do not consistently wear masks, and balked at my questions about their vaccination status. Can we set any limits?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Eric Adams Takes Office as New York City’s 110th Mayor at a Perilous Moment
description: Eric Adams, the city’s second Black mayor, faces difficult decisions over how to lead New York City through the next wave of the pandemic.
content: Eric Leroy Adams was sworn in as the 110th mayor of New York City early Saturday in a festive but pared-down Times Square ceremony, a signal of the formidable task before him as he begins his term while coronavirus cases are surging anew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: Counterculture to Counterintuitive: Cannabis to Help You Diet?
description: An edibles company says one of its products will lead not to the “the munchies” but to weight loss. There’s just one problem: the science.
content: The Fit gummies look like standard marijuana edibles: orange squares with a sugar coat, sold in packaging that’s a cross between the bright colors of a bag of candy and the sterility of a bottle of pain relievers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Katherine Clemmons
title: The Rise of Daily Run Streakers. No, Not Those Streakers.
description: Streaking has become an increasingly popular phenomenon within running circles. Whether running one mile a day, or 20, streakers push for consistency.
content: Hellah Sidibe realized that he was a streaker on his 163rd consecutive day of running.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch, Stephanie Saul, Edgar Sandoval and Mitch Smith
title: With Omicron’s Rise, Americans Brace for Returning to School and Work
description: The highly contagious variant has already contributed to flight cancellations and staffing shortages.
content: In two short weeks, as the year closed out, the Omicron variant drove coronavirus case counts to record levels, upended air travel and left gaping staffing holes at police departments, firehouses and hospitals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Trigger Warning: It’s My Brother’s Turn Again
description: Covid delayed Kevin’s annual column from the Republican point of view. But he’s back.
content: I have gotten emails asking me not to run my brother Kevin’s annual column this past year. And I have gotten emails asking me to please run Kevin’s column. I prefer to let people know what Republicans like Kevin are thinking. So here he is:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Military Focusing on ISIS Cell Behind Attack at Kabul Airport
description: The suicide bomber who killed nearly 200 people, including 13 U.S. troops, had been freed from prison by the Taliban days before the attack.
content: WASHINGTON — Four months after an Islamic State suicide bomber killed scores of people, including 13 American service members, outside the airport in Kabul, Afghanistan, U.S. and foreign intelligence officials have pieced together a profile of the assailant.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 10 Lessons We’ve Learned About Eating Well
description: Water vs. seltzer? Can food affect the brain? We’ve rounded up useful research on diet and nutrition to stay healthy in the new year.
content: As 2021 came to a close, we looked back on our reporting on diet and nutrition to glean tips we could bring into a new year. Here are 10 findings to remember next time you head to the supermarket or to the kitchen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Mann
title: Meteor Showers That Will Peak in Night Skies in 2022
description: Find a dark place. Lay back, look up and see what the cosmos has to offer.
content: On any given night, far from bright city lights, there’s a chance you’ll see a beautiful streak shoot across the sky as a meteor flies overhead. But on special dates scattered throughout the year, skywatchers can catch a multitude of flares as meteor showers burst in the darkness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Brennan, Jack Healy and Sophie Kasakove
title: After Catastrophic Fire, Colorado Fights a New Hazard: 10 Inches of Snow
description: Those whose homes survived huge fires were struggling against new threats from cold and ice. At least three people were missing and feared dead as the authorities confirmed 991 houses destroyed.
content: LOUISVILLE, Colo. — Just two days after they fled a firestorm, residents of two Colorado suburbs that had been gutted by flames slogged back home on Saturday through nearly a foot of snow and single-digit temperatures to confront a new list of woes: frozen pipes and water damage, thanks to an abrupt turn in the weather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Alabama Rolls Past Cincinnati, 27-6, in College Football Playoff Semifinal
description: The Crimson Tide will face the Georgia Bulldogs on Jan. 10 for the national championship.
content: ARLINGTON, Texas — This was the moment the Cincinnati Bearcats had pined for all season. The roster is chock-full of local kids, overlooked by Ohio State in high school and largely underestimated now by the football elite, who put their place in the College Football Playoff down to a matter of necessity: The sport needed a fourth team in the field.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Roston
title: Big Rockets, Massive Asteroids and More Space Highlights for 2022
description: Here’s a look at what may be launching in the year to come.
content: Spaceflight offered unceasing spectacles in 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Memorable Canada Stories in 2021
description: From the discovery of Indigenous graves in British Columbia to a faux Florida retirement community in Quebec, two Times Canada correspondents recall some of the standout stories of the year.
content: For those of us who report from Canada for The New York Times, it was again a year in which there was no escape from covering the pandemic. But the arrival of vaccines and the drop in infection rate (remember that?) did mean that we were again regularly traveling throughout the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: Dread, Lust and Russians
description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
content: In the previous issue of this newsletter, I asked readers about their preferred lighting setup for book consumption — and was amply rewarded. Emails poured in. Hundreds of emails! I enjoyed picturing each correspondent in the setting they described: reading by headlamp in a tent in the wilderness, nibbling butterscotch candies while beaming an illuminating neck lamp at their chosen text, or traveling with a solar lamp that resembles a gleaming gemstone. Thanks to all who wrote for providing the gift of free consumer reportage!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: British Bank Makes $175 Million in Mistaken Payments
description: Santander UK is working to collect about 75,000 payments made in error on Christmas Day to its own customers and to others who use different banks.
content: Santander UK is trying to recover about $175 million, or about 130 million pounds, that it accidentally paid tens of thousands of people on Christmas Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: College Football Gets Its Inevitable Georgia-Alabama Title Rematch
description: And Georgia is hoping that this time around, it can show Alabama much more as they play for a national championship.
content: Georgia, the defensive mammoth, and Alabama, the perennial juggernaut, seemed to be on a collision course to the top of college football all season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Louisiana Judge Who Used Racial Slur in Video Resigns
description: Michelle Odinet, of the City Court of Lafayette, La., resigned on Friday, saying in a letter that “my words did not foster the public’s confidence and integrity for the judiciary.”
content: A Louisiana judge who could be heard on a video using a racial slur while watching security footage of a foiled burglary outside her home has resigned, according to her lawyer and a letter from the judge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Dan Reeves, Coach Who Reached (but Lost) Four Super Bowls, Dies at 77
description: After years as a player and coach with the Dallas Cowboys, he went on to great success in Denver and Atlanta. He also coached the Giants, but less successfully.
content: Dan Reeves, a former Dallas Cowboys running back who, as a coach, guided teams to four Super Bowls (although he lost them all), died on Saturday at his home in Atlanta. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: People Magazine’s Premature Cover Toasts Betty White’s 100th Birthday
description: The television star, who died on Friday at age 99, shared an image of the celebrity weekly’s tribute to her earlier this week.
content: For months, editors at People magazine had been zeroing in on Betty White for an end-of-year cover article. Her 100th birthday was coming up on Jan. 17, and readers always seemed to warm to her self-deprecating, slightly naughty observations. As the toast of social media in recent years, Ms. White appealed to old and young.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz, Dani Blum, Nicole Stock, Tara Parker-Pope and Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: How high will the U.S. surge go after the holidays? Should you get tested?
description: Testing is a crucial way of helping contain the spread of the Omicron variant.
content: The United States is in the midst of a case spike averaging more than 300,000 new cases a day for the first time in the pandemic as holiday gatherings and travel coupled with the proliferation of the highly transmissible Omicron variant have propelled a surge across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Jamie McGee
title: Nashville Finds Opportunity in the Hole a Bomber Left in the Heart of the City
description: Since the explosion last Christmas, the city has grappled with how rebuilding will fit into its larger ambitions of transforming downtown. The hope is to draw more than just tourists.
content: NASHVILLE — Lower Broadway is a never-ending party, the teeming heart of the Nashville that tourists come looking for: bright lights and bars overflowing with music and crowds that can rival those in Times Square. But just around the corner, some in the city see an urgent need — and an unexpected opportunity — to create something different.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Line Just Before a Comma
description: Peter Wentz escorts us into MMXXII with a staid and sensible — never mind!
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — One day, when the universe stops expanding and begins to collapse in on itself, entropy will get the upper hand for good, and we will find ourselves entering nonsensical strings of letters into our crossword puzzles to complete them, as odd as it may feel. That day is now. Just kidding. Happy New Year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Color Mixing
description: Paolo Pasco’s Sunday puzzle presents a particularly resplendent challenge.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — In the department of very niche déjà vu, Paolo Pasco’s most recent Sunday grid appeared as the first Sunday grid of 2021. That theme revolved around dancing, and the one today calls on us to make letters shuffle and glide into new combinations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: With a Simple Funeral, South Africa Bids Farewell to Desmond Tutu
description: The archbishop and Nobel laureate left plans for an unostentatious ceremony, which were stripped back further under Covid restrictions.
content: CAPE TOWN — In an almost empty cathedral, with an unvarnished, rope-handled coffin placed before the altar, South Africa said farewell on Saturday to Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu with the simplicity that he had planned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Beaches Closed After 7 Million Gallons of Sewage Spill in Los Angeles County
description: Officials contained the spill on Friday but were still working to repair a sewer main that collapsed, leading to the release of untreated sewage into the Dominguez Channel.
content: About seven million gallons of untreated sewage have spilled into a flood-control waterway in Los Angeles County since Thursday afternoon, prompting at least five beaches to close, an official with the Los Angeles County Sanitation Districts said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Making Sense of Time When a Year Feels Lost
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 1, 2022.
content: “I like to think of a new year being possible at any moment, as every moment is a kind of doorway.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: New Year’s Day charity swims are being canceled around the world.
description: Beaches that normally spring back to life for cold-water plunges on Jan. 1 may remain deserted, as annual New Year’s Day fund-raising swims have become yet another casualty of the Omicron variant.
content: Beaches that normally spring back to life for cold-water plunges on Jan. 1 may remain deserted, as annual New Year’s Day fund-raising swims have become yet another casualty of the Omicron variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Off-Duty Officer Shot While Sleeping in Car Outside a Harlem Police Station
description: The officer was in stable condition after the shooting, which happened early on Saturday outside the 25th Precinct station house.
content: A New York City police officer was hospitalized in stable condition after being shot while sleeping in a car outside a station house in East Harlem early on Saturday, Mayor Eric Adams said at a news conference hours after he was sworn in as the city’s leader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff and Aatish Bhatia
title: When They Warn of Rare Disorders, These Prenatal Tests Are Usually Wrong
description: The false positives aren’t mentioned in the brochures for these blood screenings, which are sold by some of the biggest labs in the country.
content: After a year of fertility treatments, Yael Geller was thrilled when she found out she was pregnant in November 2020. Following a normal ultrasound, she was confident enough to tell her 3-year-old son his “brother or sister” was in her belly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: The New Political Cry in South Korea: ‘Out With Man Haters’
description: After slow gains in women’s rights, the country is facing a type of political correctness enforced by young men angry at feminists, saying they undermine opportunity.
content: SEOUL — They have shown up whenever women rallied against sexual violence and gender biases in South Korea. Dozens of young men, mostly dressed in black, taunted the protesters, squealing and chanting, “Thud! Thud!” to imitate the noise they said the “ugly feminist pigs” made when they walked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Kim Jong-un’s New Year Resolution: More Food for North Korea
description: At a party meeting, Mr. Kim made little mention of the United States or South Korea. Instead, he promised to “completely solve the food problem.”
content: SEOUL — Kim Jong-un has begun his second decade as North Korea’s leader with a vow to alleviate the country’s chronic food shortages, state media reported on Saturday — a problem that he inherited from his late father 10 years ago and has yet to fix.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 12 Things Our Critics Are Looking Forward to in 2022
description: “Better Call Saul” returns, Cecily Strong stars in a one-woman show, and Faith Ringgold gets an overdue retrospective.
content: As a new year begins in uncertain times (again), our critics highlight the TV, movies, music, art, theater, dance and comedy that promise a welcome distraction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gray Beltran
title: Here’s What Readers Told Us About Customer Service Nightmares
description: Plus, some small glimmers of hope.
content: The pandemic hasn’t been easy for consumers or service workers. While consumers have faced increased prices, shortages and long delays to receive goods and services, workers have had to deal with angry clients and to fill-in for sick co-workers, all while risking their own health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joey Roulette
title: 2022 Is Full of First Steps to the Moon
description: Debut rocket launches and robotic lunar missions will make the New Year a crucial prelude to putting astronauts back on the moon.
content: Robotic missions to Mars and advances in space tourism dominated the space activities of 2021. But in 2022, the moon is likely to stand out, as companies and governments launch various moon-bound spacecraft.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: At Least 12 Die in Stampede at a Hindu Shrine in Kashmir
description: Thousands of devotees were visiting the Mata Vaishno Devi shrine to mark the beginning of the year.
content: SRINAGAR, Kashmir — At least 12 people were killed and more than a dozen were injured in a stampede early Saturday near the city of Jammu in the Indian-controlled portion of Kashmir, as thousands of devotees were paying obeisance at a famous Hindu shrine to mark the beginning of the new year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Want a Covid Test With Your Viagra?
description: A health care company known for hair loss and erectile dysfunction treatments diversifies its product line, and earns new fans along the way.
content: Like many New Yorkers the week before Christmas, Dinah Chamberlain, 39, was on the hunt for at-home Covid-19 tests. She was going to visit her parents in Wisconsin, and she wanted to test regularly while with them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: A Vatican Library Shortens the Distance Between Its Works and Its Scholars
description: Rare books in Rome are going online thanks to a German copier, a Long Island scanning firm and a New York software company.
content: ROME — On April 13, 1923, a French prelate named Eugenio Tisserant and his assistant set sail from the Italian port city of Trieste to buy some books.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: North Carolina faces a surge, but runs into testing issues.
description: Cases have more than doubled over two weeks, and some counties have expended all their tests.
content: As the Omicron variant of the coronavirus continues to fuel a nationwide surge, North Carolina is seeing a drastic increase in Covid-19 cases. The state has reported a 166 percent increase in infections in two weeks, according to a New York Times database, and some counties are struggling to keep up with testing demands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Betty White Recalled as a Trailblazer With a Love for Life
description: “The world looks a little different now,” said the actor Ryan Reynolds, who was one of many to pay tribute to the actress who died on Friday.
content: Television stars, comedians, a president and seemingly the entire internet paid tribute on Friday to Betty White, the actress whose trailblazing career spanned seven decades and who died on Friday at her home in Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Every Day Is Jan. 6 Now
description: Though we yearn for peace and quiet, things in America are far from normal.
content: One year after from the smoke and broken glass, the mock gallows and the very real bloodshed of that awful day, it is tempting to look back and imagine that we can, in fact, simply look back. To imagine that what happened on Jan. 6, 2021 — a deadly riot at the seat of American government, incited by a defeated president amid a last-ditch effort to thwart the transfer of power to his successor — was horrifying but that it is in the past and that we as a nation have moved on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Reddy
title: 10 Insightful Tips From People Who Prove It’s Never Too Late
description: Let their stories be your inspiration as you set resolutions for 2022.
content: The arrival of a new year presents a moment to set goals and reconsider what’s possible. As the people we featured in the Times series It’s Never Too Late prove, there is no one way — and no deadline — when it comes to pursuing your dreams. We gathered some of their best words of wisdom. Let their lived experience and encouraging tips (Dream big! Don’t let fear stand in your way! Do something new!) provide you with a dash of inspiration as you set your 2022 resolutions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: A Nation on Hold Wants to Speak With a Manager
description: In our anger-filled age, when people need to shop or travel or cope with mild disappointment they’re “devolving into children.”
content: Nerves at the grocery store were already frayed, in the way of these things as the pandemic slouches toward its third year, when the customer arrived. He wanted Cambozola, a type of blue cheese. He had been cooped up for a long time. He scoured the dairy area; nothing. He flagged down an employee who also did not see the cheese. He demanded that she hunt in the back and look it up on the store computer. No luck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: A Renewed Georgia Pummels Michigan to Reach National Title Game vs. Alabama
description: The next challenge will come on Jan. 10, pandemic conditions permitting, when Alabama and Georgia will play in a rematch for the championship.
content: It was supposed to be Friday’s prizefight, the College Football Playoff semifinal showdown that might actually stay close.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Roston
title: Sync your calendar with the solar system
description: Never miss an eclipse, a meteor shower, a rocket launch or any other astronomical and space event that's out of this world.
content: Never miss an eclipse, a meteor shower, a rocket launch or any other astronomical and space event that's out of this world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Off-Duty N.Y.P.D. Officer Shot Outside East Harlem Police Station
description: New York City’s new mayor and police commissioner condemned gun violence after an officer was shot while sleeping in his personal car between shifts. Officials said that the officer was in stable condition and that the bullet appeared to be fired from a “significant distance.”
content: New York City’s new mayor and police commissioner condemned gun violence after an officer was shot while sleeping in his personal car between shifts. Officials said that the officer was in stable condition and that the bullet appeared to be fired from a “significant distance.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hillary Richard
title: Once Upon a Time … Bedtime Stories Were Just for Kids
description: But now that’s changed. In almost everyone’s never-ending quest for better sleep, the adult bedtime story industry is booming.
content: Around 10 p.m., Lindsay Colford settles into bed with the dulcet drawl of Matthew McConaughey, who is about to take her on an audio journey through the cosmos until she falls asleep. Some nights, the sound of Harry Styles delicately reciting a bedtime poem echo off the walls. And on other nights, Regé-Jean Page calmly narrates a story about an English prince.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 1, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Jan. 1, 2022.
content: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about companies and schools that are setting new requirements for booster shots misspelled the name of a New York investment bank in one instance. It is Jefferies, not Jeffries.
source.name: The New York Times
